metadata.case_number: Appeal from Patna High Court A.S. 2280 of 1948

facts.text: Respondents have been in occupation as a monthly tenant of several blocks of premises belonging to the appellants at a monthly rental of Rs. 112.
Rent for the months of March, April and May 1947 having fallen into arrears.
Respondents remitted arrears along with rent for June on 28th June 1947 by means of two cheques, which appellants did not accept.
On 4th August 1947, respondents remitted the amount by postal money order.

On 12th August 1947, appellants applied to the House Controller for eviction of respondents under section 11(1)(a) of the Bihar Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Act, 1947, maintaining non-payment of rent.
On 30th August 1947, respondents deposited rent up to June in the Office of the House Controller after money order returned by appellants.
House Controller passed order on 10th November 1947 directing eviction by 10th May 1948, holding non-payment of rent.
Order upheld by Commissioner on appeal on 27th April 1948.
Respondents filed suit in Patna Munsif's Court for declaration that Controller's order dated 10th November 1947 was illegal, ultra vires and without jurisdiction (Suit No. 62 of 1948).
Suit dismissed by Munsif; decree upheld by Subordinate Judge on appeal.
Patna High Court reversed, decreed suit holding Rent Controller's order without jurisdiction (A.S. 2280 of 1948, judgment 25th March 1949).
At inception of tenancy, respondents paid one month's rent in advance, agreed to adjust on default for full one month.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was non-payment of rent within the meaning of section 11(1)(a) of the Bihar Act, and whether the House Controller had jurisdiction to order eviction.
Whether the House Controller is competent to decide the condition precedent of non-payment of rent, and if his decision is final and cannot be questioned in a civil court.

petitioner_arguments.text: There was non-payment of rent as it was not paid as and when it fell due; rent for March due in April, April in May, no payment until 28 June 1947; advance only adjustable for one month, but three months due in monthly tenancy.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 11(1)(a) Bihar Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Act, 1947

petitioner_arguments.text: House Controller competent to decide whether condition precedent (non-payment) satisfied; once decided, cannot be questioned in civil court due to scheme of the Act.

respondent_arguments.text: No non-payment of rent in fact; eviction only if non-payment established; Controller lacked jurisdiction.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 11(1)(a) Bihar Act; interpreted with Transfer of Property Act s.111; equity against forfeiture

respondent_arguments.text: Act protects tenants; irregular payment not non-payment; Controller's decision on law questionable in court; deposit before order saves tenancy.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Preamble and object of Bihar Act to prevent unreasonable eviction

court_reasoning.text: Point is simple: respondents attack eviction order claiming no non-payment hence no jurisdiction; appellants contend non-payment as not paid when due.
Section 11 self-contained, notwithstanding any other law; no need for Transfer of Property Act; Controller decides non-payment, empowered by ss.11,16,18; decision final subject only to Commissioner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act sets complete machinery; civil court cannot question Controller's decision on jurisdictional fact.

court_reasoning.text: Cites Queen v. Commissioners: legislature entrusts tribunal jurisdiction including to determine preliminary facts; no appeal means final.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Controller given jurisdiction to decide non-payment without appeal beyond Commissioner.

court_reasoning.text: Cites Colonial Bank v. Willan: adjudication by judge with jurisdiction conclusive if no defect on face; cannot quash on erroneous fact finding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Controller's decision on non-payment not collaterally impeachable.

holdings.text: House Controller empowered to decide non-payment of rent; his decision final under the Act and not question able in civil court.
High Court's interpretation enlarging tenant protection beyond ordinary law rejected; s.11 does not import T.P. Act relief against forfeiture.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Queen v. Commissioners for Special Purposes of the Income Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature may entrust tribunal jurisdiction to determine preliminary facts; decision final if no appeal.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan
precedents_cited.relevance: Adjudication by tribunal with jurisdiction conclusive on facts; not quashable on erroneous findings.
Court decision on jurisdictional fact cannot be collaterally impeached.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Act, 1947 (Bihar Act III of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines grounds for eviction including non-payment; empowers Controller to enquire, decide bona fides, order eviction; provides appeal to Commissioner, finality of orders.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned by High Court for relief against forfeiture but rejected as inapplicable due to 'notwithstanding' clause in s.11 Bihar Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held High Court's view incorrect, upheld House Controller's jurisdiction to decide non-payment and finality of order; impliedly allowed appeal reversing High Court decree declaring Controller's order illegal.
outcome.relief_granted: Eviction order of House Controller upheld; civil suit declaration set aside.

key_quotes.text: "Section 11 is a self-contained section, and it is wholly unnecessary to go outside the Act for determining whether a tenant is liable to be evicted or not, and under what conditions he can be evicted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes Act's exclusivity over other laws like T.P. Act.

key_quotes.text: "The Act thus sets up a complete machinery for the investigation of those matters upon which the jurisdiction of the Controller to order eviction of a tenant depends, and it expressly makes his order final."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on finality and jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is not correct."
key_quotes.speaker: court
